content.title: Eclectic trip to Đà Nẵng in Vietnam

introduction.small: A large seaside city in central Vietnam, Đà Nẵng will win you over with its powerful contrasts. Here, ultra-modern skyscrapers rise up between marble mountains and fine sandy beaches.

paragraphs.text:
A lively city amidst natural wonders

Leave bustling Ho Chi Minh City behind and set off for another Vietnamese town, set to explore its architectural and natural treasures. With a lively city centre, a blissful shoreline stretching to infinity along the South China Sea and a backdrop of lush green mountains ready to unfold a thousand surprises, Đà Nẵng will certainly not disappoint. When you arrive in central Vietnam's main city, you are struck by the contrast between the forest of buildings thronging the urban centre and the surroundings.

You have selected Minh House hotel as your base. Ideally located in a quiet street, a stone's throw from the city centre and the beach, this contemporary boutique-hotel has everything to satisfy and delight. You are sure of a warm welcome from the attentive staff in this cosy hideaway with its pretty design, marrying light wood and grey stonework. You will be in seventh heaven when you realise your room looks onto the plant-filled patio with an elegant swimming pool.

Minh House
104 Tô Hiến Thành, Phước Mỹ, Sơn Trà
Đà Nẵng
Vietnam
+84 236 3550 129
www.minh-house.com/

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Refined museum and gourmet delights

So, it is now time for a wander around town. First up is the Museum of Cham Sculpture; the Cham people founded the Kingdom of Champā in the 2nd century, governing for several hundred years before being absorbed into Vietnam. Located in the south-east of Đà Nẵng, this charming museum is considered the most appealing in Vietnam, an honour it shares with the one in Hanoi. An expert guide will take you on a fascinating tour of it, which extends into a garden planted with frangipani trees, helping you to discover art which flourished from the 7th to 15th centuries. Among other pieces, you will discover terracotta bas-reliefs and sculptures which used to grace temples dedicated to the Hindu deity, Shiva.

Your visit then continues to the city's majestic pink cathedral with its mix of Gothic and Romanesque styles. This building, constructed during the French colonial period when the city was called Tourane, deserves to be explored for its magnificent stained-glass windows representing the main apostles.

Next up is the impressive Dragon Bridge spanning the River Hàn. A symbol of Đà Nẵng, it becomes even more magical at night when the lizard-like structure bursts into light. At the weekend, make your way to Bach Dang Street, on the riverside, and step onto a boat to watch a kitsch, but fairy-tale show. From 9:00 p.m., the dragon spits fire and water as the colours on the bridge change.

If all this walking has made you hungry, Đà Nẵng is famous for its varied cuisine and seafood. At Bà Dưỡng, in the Hải Châu quarter, you can start with a bánh xèo, a delicious rice-flour pancake filled with chopped pork, shrimps and bean sprouts. Or maybe you would prefer Năm Đảnh, in the Sơn Trà district, a restaurant highly acclaimed by the locals, where a fabulous array of shellfish, crab and prawns awaits, all fresh from the sea and cooked to perfection.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Lazing on one of Asia's most beautiful beaches

After this profusion of piquant flavours, why not bask a while on the divine beach of My Khe whose powder sands and translucent waters beckon you, six kilometres to the east of the city? This picture-perfect place is considered to be one of the most beautiful beaches in South-East Asia; it seduces Đà Nẵng residents and holidaymakers alike with the turquoise sea on one side and luxuriant hills on the other. Some of the locals engage in a bit of windsurfing, paddleboarding or parascending, while others nibble on dried cuttlefish gazing out at the horizon. You go for a swim in the warm waters, minding out for the currents, under the watchful eye of the lifeguards. When you get back to your towel, give in to temptation and buy a coconut water from the beach vendors. To watch the sun set, there is only one place to be – the Novotel Đà Nẵng Premier Hàn River hotel. On the 35th floor of this dazzling skyscraper overlooking the River Hàn, a surprise is in store! Sky36 Club Đà Nẵng, the highest sky bar in Vietnam, reveals its breathtaking views over the sea, the river and the majestic mountains – which you cannot wait to explore.

Novotel Đà Nẵng Premier Hàn River
36 Bạch Đằng, Thạch Thang, Hải Châu
Đà Nẵng
Vietnam
+84 236 3929 999
www.accorhotels.com/gb/hotel-8287-novotel-danang-premier-han-river/index.shtml

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Buddhist spirituality followed by a theme park

Early in the morning, a taxi takes you to the foot of the Marble Mountains, a place steeped in legend, located 12 kilometres to the south of the city. You are entering a holy place of Buddhist pilgrimage, somewhere very dear to the Vietnamese. One of the five sacred hills, Thủy Sơn, is open to visitors who climb the 156 steps up to the summit or maybe take the recently opened lift. The view from the top is out of this world – sheer poetry.

A mystical atmosphere pervades the sanctuary - a 30-metre-high cavern - with Buddha statues of all shapes and sizes, sometimes carved into the rock itself. Watch discreetly as the faithful place their offerings and burn incense sticks. Then, you go and explore the Xá Lợi pagoda. Keep your eyes peeled: over 200 Buddhas occupy the seven floors of the pagoda. But the most amazing sight is yet to come in Âm Phủ cave, better known as the Cave of Hell. You can be forgiven for being frightened in this disturbing world, where demonic statues representing the Buddhist vision of hell, rise up between astonishing stalagmites and stalactites.

For a complete change of atmosphere, head to the hill station of Bà Nà, 1,400 metres above sea level and less than an hour from the city. The former health resort built by the French during the colonial period has turned into a one-of-a-kind theme park, a sort of Vietnamese version of Disneyland. The Bà Nà Hills experience gets off to a brilliant start with a five-kilometre ride above mountains cascading with waterfalls, on board the longest cable car in the world. Its crazy attractions include crossing a golden bridge, a 150-metre-long surrealist structure supported by two giant hands, and a recreated medieval French village where you bump into dozens of awe-struck Asian tourists. For thrill-seekers, Fantasy Park boasts an indoor amusement park inspired by the novels of Jules Verne. Take your courage in both hands before throwing yourself off the top of a 29-metre-high tower on an amazing bungee jump. You can also take a seat in the high-tech cinema, where a 360-degree screen offers up one last memory of a Vietnam full of mind-blowing contrasts.

content.title: Mezz, fusion food in retro setting

introduction.small: In Ho Chi Minh City's Da Kao neighbourhood, Mezz offers à-la-minute cuisine with international flavours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mezz, fusion food in retro setting

paragraphs.text:
Inside the Sofitel Saigon Plaza, Mezz stands out with its chic retro look, attracting a trendy customer base. On the floor, black and yellow mustard concrete tiles create geometrical patterns that fit with similar colour chairs. The high ceilings of the restaurant create an inviting atmosphere in a late-20th-century New York feel, complete with long dark bench seats and an intimate mezzanine. The large buffet, also graced with that same yellow mustard tone, offers fusion food between international gastronomy and Asian flavours, while using French products. In that regard, the wine cellar is predominantly consisting of vintage bottles from that country. Different spaces develop distinct themes: grilled food, Asia, seafood, cheese and cold cuts, desserts… In the kitchen, the cooks prepare meals à la minute, bringing freshness and innovation to the buffet concept. From grilled prawns to sashimi, roasted duck, dim sum and ha kao (shrimp ravioli), there is something for everyone!

content.title: The Loft, secret café in the heart of the old town

introduction.small: Well hidden inside an old building of the Ben Thanh neighbourhood in Ho Chi Minh City, The Loft is a trendy spot that offers Vietnamese coffee and pared-down cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Loft, secret café in the heart of the old town

paragraphs.text:
Even though The Loft is located in the very centre of Ho Chi Minh City, only insiders know how to get there. At the back of a colourful paintings and drawings gallery in an old faded building, a spiral staircase leads to the upper floor where the café stands. Its minimalist appearance has been directly inspired by western industrial lofts, as well as old Parisian cafés. Furnished with rustic-looking pieces, the area is lit up through a large glass station clock.
On the menu, The Loft offers several bistro dishes – burgers and pizzas, as well as Vietnamese beef stew or fried noodles with crab meat – and, most importantly, a large selection of drinks. Sip on a refreshing fruit juice, smoothie or ice tea (various flavours are available: kumquat, passion fruit, mango…). More sophisticated, the dozen homemade non-alcoholic cocktails will assuredly spark your interest: try the Sweet Dream for instance, with kumquat, lime and cranberry, or the Cover Traffic Light with kiwi, passion fruit and grenadine syrup. Everything is ready for you to satisfy a gourmet craving and relax.

content.title: War Remnants Museum, for history enthusiasts

introduction.small: Housed in the former US Information Service building, the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh-Ville is a must for whoever wants to understand Vietnam today.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: War Remnants Museum, for history enthusiasts

paragraphs.text:
Ho Chi Minh-Ville's War Remnants Museum recounts wars and conflicts that took place in Vietnam with reconstructions, photographs by wartime correspondents and information panels. At first named “Museum of Chinese and American wartime crimes”, it was given its current name in 1996 for the sake of pacification between nations. This historical place spreads over two floors, where exhibitions tell of the various atrocities carried upon Vietnamese people by enemy troops, such as the My Lai massacre or the use of the infamous Agent Orange on civilians.
The visit continues on the first floor, with the discovery of the “White Dove” room, where children's drawings are exhibited. Through painting, kids have been able to express their desires, such as a peaceful life, going to school or simply having a little bit of fun.
In the courtyard, you can admire gigantic American war machines salvaged from the battlefields: aircrafts, tanks and even helicopters. A very moving museum, filled with historic and unexpected stories.

introduction.small: Across from the Independence Palace, Quan An Ngon 138 allows you to discover the diversity of Vietnamese cuisine at unbeatable prices.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Quan An Ngon 138: typically Vietnamese

Located in a huge pale ochre colonial home, Quan An Ngon 138 is set up inside like a traditional house in ‘Ruong' style, with painted wooden balustrades, furniture with subtle inlaid pearl present everywhere on the stairs, balconies, and tables.

This restaurant was established around the idea of ​​bringing together in one place many chefs in the city who excel in a particular dish. So you are guaranteed to taste typical Vietnamese dishes. The challenge is to choose from a wide and varied assortment that includes not only pho (beef) or lau (crab) soup and grilled meats, but also banh xeo (rice pancake), muc xao (fried squid) tom hap dua (shrimp steamed in coconut juice) or banh cuon (spring rolls). Quan An Ngon 138 gives you all of Vietnam on a plate!

content.title: Pizza 4 P's: pizza ‘made in Vietnam'

introduction.small: Run by a Japanese chef who is a specialist in pizza and Neapolitan pasta, this restaurant is an institution for Ho Chi Minh City's expatriate community.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pizza 4 P's: pizza ‘made in Vietnam'

paragraphs.text:
Finding this restaurant isn't easy as it's down a narrow alley behind the sushi bar, on Le Thanh Ton street, but it is well worth it. The locals claim that they serve some of the best pizzas in Saigon and even all of Vietnam... The chef, who is Japanese, is a lover of Vietnam, passionate about Italian food, and mindful of eating in a healthy way. This gives an impassioned result that is very popular with expatriates. They find themselves among large crowds at lunch and dinner in this elegantly designed restaurant.

As for the food, you must absolutely taste the miso salmon pizza – but also pastas. There is spaghetti served with tomato and mascarpone sauce, caprese pasta, Japanese style carbonara with homemade camembert cheese, or pasta with crab. Everything is excellently presented—the Japanese touch and the attention to detail are quickly recognized—and all is served by knowledgeable and attentive staff. Above all, remember to book in advance because of those crowds.

content.title: Park Hyatt Saigon: a legendary palace

introduction.small: Its view of the opera house and its exceptional location a few blocks from Dong Khoi Street are not the only treasures contained in this French colonial-style palace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Park Hyatt Saigon: a legendary palace

paragraphs.text:
Opposite the Municipal Theatre/Saigon Opera House and Lam Son Square, the Park Hyatt Saigon imposes its style. Modernised with elegance, the French colonial spirit still lingers in this discreetly chic palace. The key lies in the details. The epitome of elegance is reflected in the hospitality services, such as the butler service provided 24/7, and a host of other little touches that make all the difference, complemented by the comfort of the rooms, which are as luxurious as the service.

In the heart of bustling Saigon, this exceptional property is an enchanting enclave. At the edge of the amazing 20-metre-long outdoor pool, it is difficult to imagine the endless stream of motorbikes buzzing just on the other side. Relaxing at the spa of the Park Hyatt Saigon is another possibility for extending this great escape, while other moments of grace await you on the menus at the Park Lounge bar, with its renowned cocktails, and two restaurants, the Square One and the Opera.

content.title: Vespa Adventures on the road to discovery

introduction.small: The more adventurous will jump at the opportunity of discovering Saigon on a vintage Vespa, while others continue the adventure towards the Mekong Delta for a more exotic getaway.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vespa Adventures on the road to discovery

Exploring the country roads of the Mekong Delta on a vintage Vespa is a unique experience. Off the beaten track, you will cross dozens of bridges, board a ferry to a traditional floating market, then cut through the rice fields to reach a local restaurant, where you can even put a line in and taste the fish you catch for lunch.
Equally authentic, but reserved for those who are not fazed by the roaring jungle of Saigon, the discovery of the city on a Vespa is a memorable escape. You can ride through streets hidden away in the Cholon district, discover the flower market, a Buddhist pagoda, and other local landmarks like the Opera House and Central Post Office. At night, the glow of the headlights and the atmosphere becomes even more magical.

content.title: Discovering the most beautiful pagodas in Saigon

introduction.small: Though religious ritual is not formalised in the temples and pagodas, there are no visits without burning incense. Closed in 1945, these places of worship are being rediscovered today.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discovering the most beautiful pagodas in Saigon

paragraphs.text:
Previously closed or converted into schools and granaries, temples and pagodas can again welcome the faithful, although the authorities continue to closely monitor all aspects of the sacred. Offerings in the form of incense sticks play an essential role in the celebration of worship. The number of burned sticks varies depending on the occasion, but the total must always be odd. According to Vietnamese belief, odd numbers are for the dead, even numbers are reserved for the living.

In Ho Chi Minh City, the flamboyant pagoda of the Jade Emperor is one of the most fascinating. Built by Canton Buddhists who settled in Saigon, its architecture is typically modelled after southern China. In the small street called Lao Tu, Quan Am Pagoda, founded by Chinese from Fukien in 1740, is probably the oldest of all.

content.title: Six Senses Ninh Van Bay: a narrow escape

introduction.small: Designed in harmony with nature to better blend into the background, this dream hotel lies in a bay of wild charm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Six Senses Ninh Van Bay: a narrow escape

paragraphs.text:
You will open the doors to a dream when arriving at the entrance of the protected area of Six Senses Ninh Van Bay in the Nha Trang region. A castaway's wonder on the other side of the planet, it's only an hour flight from Ho Chi Minh City. In a bay cut off from the world, cliffs covered with lush jungle growth plunge into the South China Sea surrounded by a heavenly beach of white sand.

Dense green, celadon hues and bright reflections, and an incredible palette of colours together reveal the beauty of this hidden treasure. On the hill, on the seafront, or hidden in the rocks, suites and villas blend with the surrounding nature that remains incredibly well preserved. As a sanctuary, the traditional Vietnamese spa contributes greatly to the fame of the place. The restaurant menu reflects the same natural spirit of a healthy mind and a healthy body.

content.title: Saigon Central Post Office: authentic charm by mail

introduction.small: The metal structure of the Saigon Central Post Office, one of the finest remnants of colonial architecture, was designed by Gustave Eiffel. Its legend continues.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saigon Central Post Office: authentic charm by mail

paragraphs.text:
Sending postcards will no longer be a chore! On your trip to Ho Chi Minh City, the Saigon Central Post Office will make you want to write for the pleasure of sending your mail. Right next to the red brick Notre-Dame Cathedral, the yellow building was built between 1886 and 1891 by the administration of the French Post, on plans made by Auguste-Henri Villedieu.
The unaltered charm of its colonial architecture is perhaps even more striking inside. Under a metal frame designed by Gustave Eiffel, 30 genuine windows align. Arches, carved wooden panels, original frescoes, antique telephone booths, old pots of glue for stamps, and spaces for writing—our modern age does not seem to have control over the Saigon Central Post Office, where only cell phones betray the feeling that you've travelled back in time.

content.title: Silverland Sakyo Hotel & Spa: genteel, discreet charm

introduction.small: The refined modernism and traditional codes of this hotel create a peaceful refuge in the heart of ‘Little Tokyo', one of the liveliest districts of Saigon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Silverland Sakyo Hotel & Spa: genteel, discreet charm

On the hotel's porch, above the magisterial entrance, silk lanterns swaying in the wind set the tone. Up the stairs, traditional cement tiles guide the steps of travellers from the lobby, which seems to have been overwhelmed by nature and, in particular, by the branches of cherry blossom trees which subtly fall from the ceiling.

Welcome to Silverland Sakyo Hotel, a haven of peace and understated zen spirit, which is at the heart of ‘Little Tokyo', one of the most animated areas of Ho Chi Minh City. The hotel's serenity is equally striking in the spacious rooms, where exotic wood-slat blinds filter the light. On the roof, right next to the spa, another bubble of wellness is offered, where the view of the city from the Jacuzzi pool invites contemplation and meditation.

content.title: With its opera arias, the municipal theatre still enchants

introduction.small: To discover what is hidden behind the majestic neoclassical facade, attend a dance show or a classical music concert.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: With its opera arias, the municipal theatre still enchants

paragraphs.text:
A replica of the Petit Palais in Paris, built the same year, the Municipal Theatre is a small architectural wonder, a relic of French colonial heritage. Influenced by the flamboyant style of the French Third Republic, especially by the architecture of the Opera Garnier in Paris, its majestic facade, where two statues have supported the entry dome since 1900, is the work of architect Eugène Ferret.

Decorations, inscriptions, and furniture, which were designed by artists specially sent from France, have lost nothing of their former glory. Today, the Saigon Opera is not open for visits, but regularly scheduled dance and classical music events offer the perfect opportunity to discover this neoclassical room. For the programme, simply visit the website and book tickets online.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Merci: a hedonistic nail bar for a gourmet break

Though the menu displays specialty cocktails, there is an array of tempting sweets, dishes to share or not, among other enticing suggestions. Upstairs, the tables have been replaced by a cosy lounge conducive to leisurely body palpation. content.title: L'Usine: a trendy cafeteria in an old workshop

introduction.small: On the first floor of a building in popular Dong Khoi Street, the kitchens of L'Usine are in full swing in a former workshop.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'Usine: a trendy cafeteria in an old workshop

L'Usine is a real discovery. We must first take a walkway between two shops, climb to the first floor by the stairs at the end of this alley lined with stalls and motorcycles, and walk along a tiled corridor of black and white that opens onto a courtyard of pure colonial style. Here, in this old workshop behind the large glass swing doors, is a lively cafeteria of a new genre in Ho Chi Minh City.

The authenticity of the place is not just in its industrial style, marble tables, and steel chairs, which seem an obvious choice in the context. It is also found on your plate. From breakfast, which is served all day, through dinner, offering duck à l'orange and baked potatoes, salmon croquettes in a garlic and spices sauce, or even ratatouille with cabbage and melted pecorino cheese, the menu offers fresh, inspired Vietnamese cuisine, prepared on site by expert hands. content.title: Cholon: the Chinatown of Ho Chi Minh City

introduction.small: With a slightly French air represented by vestiges of colonial architecture, the Cholon district has kept its Chinese character with its ever-fascinating bustling markets.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cholon: the Chinatown of Ho Chi Minh City

paragraphs.text:
In the Cholon (‘big market') district, the main shopping hall, with its mustard-yellow facade and roof adorned with sinuous dragons, is visible from far away. A wholesale market above all, Binh Tay Market is one of the most authentic of the city. It is difficult to get through the aisles, which are agitated by a constant back and forth of goods' carts overloaded with stuffed animals, anti-pollution masks, artificial flowers, and colourful garlands.

The surrounding streets are equally alive. The most interesting sights are concentrated in the southwestern sector. The rich ornamentation of temples and pagodas, the taste of Cholon's food and its lively shops maintain the legend of a neighbourhood established in the late 18th century by the Hoa, an ethnic group native to southwestern China.

content.title: The Alcove Library Hotel: on the right page

introduction.small: At the corner of a quiet lane, this quaint hotel tells its tale in the pages of its impressive library, encouraging you to write a new chapter in your journey.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Alcove Library Hotel: on the right page

paragraphs.text:
Crossing the garden, it is hard to believe that this authentic building now houses a luxury hotel as discreet as its access from the picturesque alley. In the quieter Phu Nhuan district, The Alcove Library Hotel is sheltered from the bustle of downtown. Novels, art books, and, indeed, an incredible number of books of all kinds, which seem to have been left by travellers from all walks, line the shelves of the impressive library, which is visible upon entry to the establishment.

You need to pass through it to better discover the place; remember to borrow a few volumes on your way. The rooms, which are exercises in refined simplicity, open like blank pages to better let the imagination wander. On the top floor, the Bookmark restaurant adds another chapter with its breath-taking views of Saigon to help you continue writing the story of your journey.

content.title: Saigon Cooking Classes by Hoa Tuc: cooking in a peripatetic school

introduction.small: Discover Vietnamese cuisine off the beaten track, in group classes or at the market on a scooter with the chef, and enjoy the best local specialties.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saigon Cooking Classes by Hoa Tuc: cooking in a peripatetic school

paragraphs.text:
A good appetite is a great excuse for exploring and discovering a city like Ho Chi Minh City. Walk, visit, enjoy, and be guided by an experienced chef—this is what the Saigon Cooking Class by Hoa Tuc offers. By taxi or on the back of a scooter, the tour begins with a visit to a local market, followed by the discovery of the best street vendors and favourite ‘canteens', and a tasting of Vietnamese specialties. The cooking classes also begin with a trip to the market led by the chef to choose the ingredients needed to prepare a meal of four dishes.

Spices, fresh herbs, and fruits and vegetables from around the country make up the recipes that the chef will help you develop. Specialties such as mustard leaves rolled with crunchy vegetables and shrimp or spicy beef salad with kumquat, lemongrass, and aubergines—all that remains is for you to enjoy a ‘Tra Da': the must-try iced green tea served throughout Vietnam.

content.title: Le Cong Kieu Street: the street of antique shops

introduction.small: In this quiet street, there are rows of narrow shops full of treasures. A real find, among many others, for an authentic, timeless stroll.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Cong Kieu Street: the street of antique shops

paragraphs.text:
The small shops of Le Cong Kieu Street are full of treasures, bric-a-brac of all kinds, decorative objects, and furniture of Asian or colonial style. Formerly ‘rue de Reims', this quiet street, long known for being the ‘street of antique shops', is still a paradise for bargain hunters.

The stalls, stretching lengthwise and open to the street, are overwhelmed with inlaid mother of pearl chessboards, bronze Art Deco lamps, old radios, lacquerware, porcelain, and ceramics. In front of the stalls, the inhabitants of these old houses play checkers unabated. Time is suspended in this street, which seems as peaceful as it was a century ago. With its unique setting, historically rich objects, and characters from another time, you'll have plenty of unforgettable memories to bring back from your trip.

Le Cong Kieu Street

content.title: The Refinery: a bistro in a former opium factory

introduction.small: The peaceful terrace of this bistro, which was originally an opium refinery, is, in fact, today one of the hottest addresses in town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Refinery: a bistro in a former opium factory

paragraphs.text:
74 Hai Ba Trug has always been a well-known address in Saigon. Built in 1881 to house the ‘Manufacture d'Opium', the building has today lost none of its lustre. It now houses an authentic bistro with a shaded terrace, and the tranquillity of the place provides a preview of what awaits you at this gourmet address.
Whether for brunch—which is especially prized—lunch, or dinner, the continental cuisine that is served here is homemade, like the pork ribs in apple and endives, grilled salmon, grilled eggplant, crisp risotto balls and pesto sauce, or frozen cheesecake with passion fruit coulis. As for the wine list, which is as generous as the dishes, it pleasantly complements the bistro atmosphere.

content.title: Home shopping spree in Saigon

introduction.small: Here are three select addresses where you can find wonders, signed by French designers, in the universe of decoration and household linen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Home shopping spree in Saigon

paragraphs.text:
In Vietnam, furniture and traditional lacquered pieces are a must. After signing a number of large pieces, designer Bruno de Caumont has also created objects that are easier to take away. The Villa Verte, which has retained the charm of the 1950s, has become his showroom. Lovers of extreme refinement will inevitably be seduced.

The French art of living is also found in Diabolo, which offers colourful design furniture and decorative accessories. Finally, Saigon-based French designer Catherine Denoual has become the reference when it comes to luxury home textiles in Vietnam. We find, through her eponymous label, hand-embroidered bed linen, linen tablecloths, and ornaments for baby's room, made of the finest materials.

content.title: Hoa Tuc: an explosion of flavours!

introduction.small: The originality of Hoa Tuc (meaning ‘Poppy Flower') is to provide a contemporary Vietnamese cuisine in a stunning Art Deco decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hoa Tuc: an explosion of flavours!

paragraphs.text:
Like The Refinery, Hoa Tuc restaurant is located in an old opium refinery of the colonial era, in the middle of a courtyard that houses a small group of restaurants and various new entertainment addresses. The pergola at the entrance, made of cast iron and frosted glass, is inspired by the underground entrances in vogue in Paris in the early 1900s. The front terrace is a lively place, where diners can pleasantly enjoy a lunch menu and observe the activity of the courtyard.

As for the food, it will delight the most discerning palates, with personal touches that make it particularly endearing. As a starter, you can choose the fried egg rolls with fresh delicate flavours, the mustard leaf rolls with crunchy vegetables and shrimp, or north-Vietnamese stuffed dumplings with pork, mushroom and lemony soy sauce. Next you can throw your heart into the caramelised chicken with ginger and fish sauce, the pulled pork, marinated in a coconut juice, or even the chow mein with beef and vegetables. The wine list, prepared by a renowned sommelier, is one of the richest in Vietnam. For all these reasons, bookings are highly recommended.

content.title: TukTuk Thai Bistro: on the road of flavours

introduction.small: In the centre of Saigon, this contemporary bistro delights with its inventive Thai cuisine, making it one of the most surprising tables of the moment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: TukTuk Thai Bistro: on the road of flavours

paragraphs.text:
For chef Saran Jittiboonruan, born in Bangkok, the tuk tuk was a symbol close to his heart when opening the first modern Saigon bistro to offer inventive Thai cuisine. It is a subtle evocation for his guests as they embark on a road of flavours that remains to be explored. From discovery to discovery, the menu offers lunch and dinner stops featuring the house specialties.

Soups, salads, and even the most traditional Thai dishes are always inflected by East/West influences, a fusion that has made the reputation of this inventive table. Dishes such as fried chicken wings with lemongrass, honey-marinated grilled pork served with a tamarind “northeast” sauce, or vegetarian Thai curry delight the senses. The cuisine, which has a contemporary twist, is highly colourful in this black-and-white atmosphere, present from the ground floor to the rooftop terrace, which itself is another great discovery.

content.title: Small stories of great hotels

introduction.small: The largest hotels in Saigon could alone tell the story of the city. The Continental, the Caravelle, and the Majestic still bear witness today.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Small stories of great hotels

paragraphs.text:
The finest hotels in the city are a living reminder of the captivating past of the formerly colonial Saigon. On Lam Son Square, the Hotel Continental, built in 1880, still embodies the French style. Stopping in to take tea in the plush lounges is a wonderful experience for a glimpse of the refined art-de-vivre that diplomats and the cream of colonial society valued so much.

On the other side of the square, another venerable institution faces the Continental. During the Vietnam War, the Caravelle, was the headquarters of the Associated Press. On the top floor, the current Saigon Saigon Bar was the office for many correspondents and journalists, and remains one of the best places to enjoy the sunset over the city.

Further along on the banks of the river, another historic palace retains an unaltered allure. Built on the model of the hotels of the Cote d'Azur in France, the Majestic, overlooking the Saigon River, offers a break of incomparable charm.

content.title: Visiting the old colonial Saigon

introduction.small: Going down the rue Catinat (Catinat Street) takes you back in time. It's a nice walk, in the footsteps of the French, which starts at the Square of the Paris Commune.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visiting the old colonial Saigon

paragraphs.text:
There are still some colonial arcaded houses in what used to be the rue Catinat, now called ‘Dong Khoi'. The walk begins at the Square of the Paris Commune in the footsteps of French architects who set the tone for the city, between Notre-Dame Cathedral and the Central Post Office.

Behind its majestic salmon-coloured facade, the Central Post Office, supported by metal structures designed by Gustave Eiffel, still has the same allure. A little lower, the Hotel Continental has also retained its former glory. A legendary hotel, it faces the municipal theatre, whose neoclassical facade is the work of the French architect Eugene Ferret. Just before arriving at the Saigon River, the Grand and Majestic hotels are the last witnesses of this style of hotel, vestiges of a nostalgic era.

Dong Khoi
District 1
70000 Ho Chi Minh City

content.title: Social Club: one of the best rooftops in the city

introduction.small: Perched on the 23rd floor of the Hotel des Arts Saigon MGallery, the Social Club is a restaurant-bar with a rooftop terrace that offers breath-taking views of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Social Club: one of the best rooftops in the city

paragraphs.text:
The rooftop terrace of the Social Club is a marvel you discover once you reach the 23rd floor of the Hotel des Arts Saigon MGallery Collection. It is best to do so at night, when the view of the city, enhanced by the twinkling lights, is absolutely exceptional.

The exclusive creation of the famous Japanese architects of Studio Super Potato, this restaurant-bar has become, since its recent opening, the place to see and be seen. Outside, the atmosphere has a surreal edge, the DJ having put his turntables in a submerged cabin at the end of the huge pool. Inside, the authentic wooden bar, found in an antique shop in London, defines the gentlemen's club-like atmosphere of intimacy. While admiring the breath-taking panorama, enjoy modern European food prepared with fresh seasonal ingredients, such as tuna ceviche or tartare Saint-Jacques, like you've rarely eaten!

content.title: Ben Thanh Market: the hall of treasures

introduction.small: A shopping centre of choice for travellers and Saïgonnais, Ben Thanh Market is one of the most vibrant and colourful in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ben Thanh Market: the hall of treasures

paragraphs.text:
With its main entrance crowned by a belfry and a clock, Ben Thanh Market has become an emblem of the city. A strategic meeting point for travellers and Saïgonnais alike, this hall, with an area of 11,000 square metres, invites discovery. New stalls have appeared aimed primarily at the local trade.

Jade jewellery, traditional silk clothing, rattan baskets, and so many evocative memories of Vietnam, such as conical hats and chopsticks, crowd the small alleys, through which it is sometimes difficult to make one's way. Basic foods as well as fruits and vegetables occupy the back of the hall.

At the close of the market, small vendors set up to offer authentic Vietnamese cuisine. It is a great opportunity to experience the charm of this old colonial town at night.
